data.title: Sam Shepard
data.meta_description: News about Sam Shepard, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
data.text:
Read Your Way Through Los Angeles

Héctor Tobar is a son of Los Angeles, a city of “perpetual cultural mixing.” Here, he guides readers through the books and writers that cut through the city’s layers.

By Héctor Tobar

Nonfiction

Sam Shepard and the Art of Expressing the Unsaid

“True West” is a new biography of a playwright and actor who was laconic in person but spoke volumes in his work.

By Dwight Garner

How Chuck Yeager’s ‘Right Stuff’ Hit the Screen

The test pilot, who died Monday at 97, inspired generations after he was featured in the book and film “The Right Stuff.” Here’s how it came about.

critic’s notebook

Finding the Sweet, Stinging Salt in Plays of Confinement

For stuck-at-homes feeling like submerging into the existential depths of no-exit theater, here’s a list of works to read and to watch.

By Ben Brantley

with …

Rock Star Patti Smith, Making Paris Swoon

She is working toward a third act as a novelist, and her new book, “Year of the Monkey,” blends fact and fiction.

By Maureen Dowd

‘Oh! Calcutta!’ at 50: Still Naked After All These Years

John Lennon and Sam Shepard wrote sketches. The cast was unclothed. And it went on to a two-decade Broadway run. An oral history of one of theater’s unlikeliest hits.

By Alexis Soloski

Critic's Notebook

Does Anything Awful Happen to the Cat in the Play?

On the dread, and the glory, of watching animals onstage.

By Laura Collins-Hughes

Review: In ‘Curse of the Starving Class,’ a House Is Really Divided

Terry Kinney’s unbalanced Sam Shepard revival, with Maggie Siff and David Warshofsky, finds the prophecy in a wild and woolly play from the 1970s.

By Ben Brantley

Critic’s Pick

Review: Ethan Hawke and Paul Dano Go Mano a Mano in the Riveting ‘True West’

In this unsettling revival, directed by James Macdonald, two fine actors find the existential terror in Sam Shepard’s portrait of battling brothers.

By Ben Brantley
